summary.seg: This manuscript is a composite made up of small parts copied at a variety of dates from the 13th to the 16th centuries. It contains a variety of Greek grammatical, rhetorical and philosophical texts. The oldest part, copied in the late 13th or early 14th century, contains three orations by the 4th-century rhetorician Libanios. The date and the use of eastern paper indicate that it was produced in the Greek-speaking world. Another portion, from the mid-15th century, contains another oration of Libanios and a short lexical text. A third part contains a fragment of a text by Andromachos of Crete, physician to the Emperor Nero (37-68 CE). This was copied by the Italian scribe Bartolomeo Zanetti, a native of Brescia who worked in Venice, Florence and Rome, in the first half of the 16th century. The longest part, also from the 16th century and probably also produced in Italy, contains a series of brief texts and excerpts, some anonymous, others from the works of the 1st century BCE historian and teacher of rhetoric Dionysios of Halikarnassos and the 4th century CE philosopher Maximos Byzantios.

The manuscript, or at least the older parts of it, was owned by the Venetian humanist Cardinal Domenico Grimani (1460-1523). It later came into the hands of the scholar Isaac Casaubon (1559-1614), and then those of Thomas Gale (c. 1635-1702), whose son Roger Gale (1672-1744) donated it to Trinity College along with the rest of his collection.
A previous binding for the manuscript reused a fragment of a 16th-century French document as a wrapper.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [a-c] + I-II + 1-52 + [d-f], in pencil, in Roman numerals, recto, upper right, and Arabic numerals, recto, in the lower half of the right-hand margin.

ff. 1-14 have an older foliation in Arabic numerals, recto, upper right. Some numbers have been corrected. On ff. 15-17 a new foliation sequence in this position runs 3-5; ff. 18-20 are unfoliated in this position. Another new sequence in this position appears on ff. 21-52, running 1-32.

binding.p: 20th-century binding with marbled paper covering over pasteboards, with a white parchment spine and plain pastedowns. The classmark appears on the spine on patches.

history.provenance: Owned by Cardinal Domenico Grimani (1460-1523) Grimani, Domenico, 1460-1523 .
Owned by the classical scholar Isaac Casaubon (1559-1614) Casaubon, Isaac, 1559-1614 .

Owned by the antiquary Thomas Gale (c. 1635-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635?-1702 , Fellow of Trinity and Dean of York. It appears in the 1697 catalogue of Gale's collection contained in Trinity College MS O.5.38 (p. 165).
history.acquisition: Donated by Thomas's son, the antiquary Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744 , in 1738.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

msItem.title: Fragment of a deed
msItem.note: Signed Mellas and P. Douffe (?), with what appear to be notarial signs.

supportDesc.condition: The inner sides of the two parchment leaves are grimy around all four edges, suggesting that these may have been formed the outer side of the binding, before they were separated from the rest of the contents and rebound as endleaves at the front of the manuscript. The two upper corners are heavily creased.

layout.seg: A single column of text, more than 16 lines (rest lost due to reuse and trimming), unruled.

handDesc.handNote: ff. i verso-ii recto were written in a French secretary script.

physDesc.additions: A Greek note has been addded on f. ii recto.

binding.p: Multiple pricking holes along the gutter of this bifolium indicates that it was used as a wrapper for some or all of the contents of this composite manuscript. It likely remained in place as the wrapper at least until the manuscript came to Trinity College: f. II verso bears a rectangular stain corresponding to the size and shape of the college bookplate.

origin.origDate: This document was probably written in the 16th century in

supportDesc.condition: The leaves have been badly damaged along all four edges, and the paper stabilised and repaired extensively with Japanese tissue paper.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1r-6v A single column of 31 lines.
205 135

handNote.p: ff. 1r-6v were copied by Hand B in Fettaugen-style mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, with significant variation in letter size, in black ink.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and abbreviations.
The modern nu and sigma telikon are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop.

decoDesc.decoNote: Texts begin with simple minor initials in red ink.
Transitions between texts are marked by line-fillers in red ink.

history.origin: This part was probably copied in the second half of the 13th or 14th century, as suggested by the style of script and use of eastern paper.

msItem.title: Lexicon
msItem.note: Excerpt: begins with gamma, ends with epsilon

msItem.title: Orationes 1-64
msItem.note: Defective at the end: ends ed. Foerster, section 2

support.material: ff. 7-12 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Crown ( 58 31 ) roughly in the centre of the folio, similar to Briquet 4730. This example is dated to 1437-1439.

supportDesc.condition: The leaves have suffered water damage along the upper edge and extending up to a third of the way down the leaves, with discolouration of the paper and some blurring of the lines of text closest to the upper edge and of scholia in the margins. The continuation of similar patterns of staining in the following section of the manuscript indicates that these two parts were bound together at the time that they were damaged in this way, but not with the other contents of the manuscript.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 7r-12v A single column of 31-49 lines.
205-210 145

handNote.p: ff. 7r-12r were copied by Hand C in mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in brown ink, with moderate variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and abbreviations.
The modern modern eta , modern nu, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma and full stop.

physDesc.additions: On 12v there are pen trials and three sketches of heads in profile.

history.origin: This part was probably copied in the second quarter of the 15th century, as suggested by the watermark. This is consistent with the style of script.

msItem.author: Andromachos of Crete (the Elder)
msItem.title: Fragment
msItem.incipit: f. 13r ÎÎ»ÏÎ¸Î¹ ÏÎ¿Î»Ï Î¸ÏÎ¿Î½Î¯Î¿Ï Î²ÏÎ¹Î±Ïá½¸Î½ ÏÎ¸Î­Î½Î¿Ï á¼Î½ÏÎ¹Î´ÏÏÎ¿Î¹Î¿

support.material: ff. 13-20 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Arrows ( c. 65 38 ) in the gutter, similar to Briquet 6289 and Sosower Fleche 19. These examples are dated to 1511 and 1542.

supportDesc.condition: The leaves have suffered water damage along the upper edge and extending up to a third of the way down the leaves, with discolouration of the paper. The continuation of similar patterns of staining from the previous section of the manuscript indicates that these two parts were bound together at the time that they were damaged in this way, but not with the other contents of the manuscript.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 13r-19r A single column of 14 lines 165-170 100-115
Frame and line ruling in hardpoint.

handNote.p: ff. 13r-19r were copied by Bartolomeo Zanetti (Hand D) (RGK I 31) in mixed minuscule script, slanting sharply to the right, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot. Accents are sometimes joined to abbreviations.
The modern modern eta , modern nu, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present.
Punctuation used includes the lower and middle points, lower commas and full stop.

decoDesc.decoNote: The text begins with a simple minor initial in red ink.

physDesc.additions: On f. 13r are notes on the text in Latin by later hands.

history.origin: This part was copied in Italy by Bartolomeo Zanetti (1486/7-c. 1547) Zanetti, Bartholomeo, 1486 or 1487- in the first half of the 16th century, as indicated by the watermark and the scribe's period and region of activity.

support.material: ff. 21-52 Western paper, folded in octavo. Watermark: Circles ( 100 33 ) on the upper edge of the folio near the gutter, similar to Briquet 3165. This example is dated to 1329-1339.

collation.p: This part consists of four quires, all quaternia:
collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower centre.

supportDesc.condition: The leaves have suffered water damage along the three outer edges, causing discolouration which sometimes impinges upon the text. Some edges and corners of the leaves have been repaired.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 21r-52v A single column of 24-28 lines. 150-165 100-115

handNote.p: ff. 21r-50v were copied by Hand E in upright mixed minuscule script, in brown ink, with moderate variation in letter size and some flourishing of tails into the margin.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and abbreviations.
The modern nu and sigma telikon are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma and full stop.
f. 51r-51v were copied by Hand F in mixed minuscule script, in brown ink, with variable slant, with moderate variation in letter size.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round.
The modern eta and modern nu are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points and lower comma.
f. 52r-52v were copied by Hand G in Latin and Greek mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in brown ink.

history.origin: This part was probably copied in the first half of the 14th century, as suggested by the watermark. This is consistent with the style of script.
